feed.title: Combined summary - Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks

entry.title: Combined summary - Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks
entry.summary:
In a comprehensive examination of the cryptocurrency mixing services provided by Wasabi and other coinjoin implementations, Yuval Kogman presents a detailed critique of their vulnerabilities and the potential for deanonymization. Kogman, leveraging his expertise in the development of the joinstr protocol and contributions to Wasabi, highlights the limitations and misconceptions surrounding these services. Notably, he addresses the challenges in accurately calculating coordinator earnings, critiquing the misrepresentation of services as 'free' when, in reality, they generate substantial revenue, approximately 0.2 bitcoin per month. This discrepancy raises concerns about user consent and the transparency of service costs.
The email delves into technical critiques, particularly focusing on the implementation of Wasabi coinjoins, where policies allowed excess fees to be claimed by the coordinator, exploiting what Kogman identifies as a leniency bug. He suggests that this practice diverges from the precedent that surplus fees would contribute towards mining fees, pointing out a lack of adequate justification or documentation for such changes. The discussion extends to broader issues of transparency, informed consent, and ethical conduct within the development and promotion of cryptocurrency services, emphasizing the need for clear communication regarding service operations and costs.
Kogman brings attention to the nuanced debate surrounding financial disclosures for work shared within professional forums, shedding light on broader discussions within the Bitcoin development community about transparency expectations. He references his previous publications, which acknowledged financial support, to underline the importance of disclosing financial backing in contributing to the ecosystem. The discourse also covers the operational realities of implementing privacy features within Bitcoin transactions, highlighting the critical security concern of sybil attacks and the necessity of transaction fees for safeguarding against such vulnerabilities.
Further, the conversation explores technical specifics and vulnerabilities associated with tagging attacks, aiming to deanonymize users through adversarial tactics. Kogman critiques the failure to implement robust mitigations against such strategies, questioning the absence of stronger measures previously outlined. He proposes alternative mitigation strategies, emphasizing the need for a transparent, well-informed approach to enhancing user anonymity and security in cryptocurrency transactions.
In addition to addressing technical vulnerabilities, Kogman scrutinizes the effectiveness of existing privacy protection measures and advocates for honest and integrity-driven discussions on privacy vulnerabilities and solutions. He highlights the intricacies of cryptographic signatures, specifically examining the possibility of creating valid signature tuples with substitute public keys under Schnorr and ECDSA schemes, illustrating the challenges and security features inherent to each.
Lastly, Kogman's critique includes an analysis of the coordination vulnerabilities in Wasabi & GingerWallet and the CoinJoin protocols, emphasizing the deanonymization risks stemming from fundamental design issues. He underscores the persistent trust issues between users and coordinators, further complicated by coordinators' behaviors and competencies. Through a technical breakdown of vulnerabilities within the Whirlpool and WabiSabi protocols, Kogman points out the critical flaws allowing malicious coordinators to deanonymize transactions, underscoring the need for rigorous standards of security and user trust in evolving cryptocurrency protocols.
